section.name: Cayenne News
section.p:
This is both the first Beta release of Cayenne and a major feature enhancement. It adds features that were a must-have for Cayenne maturity, introduces serious performance enhancements, expands the number of fully supported databases and fixes numerous bugs. For details see the release notes. Download the release from here. Among other things in this release:
Support for stored procedures.
Support for BLOB/CLOB.
Data operation dependency tracking based on Ashwood.
Support for PostgreSQL and HSQLDB.
Batched data modification operations.
Note on deprecated API: There is lots of deprecated API in this release. All deprecated code will be preserved for a while, but will NOT be included in the final 1.0 release. Make sure to replace calls to the deprecated methods and classes in your applications with suggested alternatives.

During the playoffs, NHL.com services over a million page views per day. ObjectStyle and Central Park Software teamed up to create a new player/team statistics engine based on Cayenne with JSP frontend and Oracle backend. The project was successfully launched in October at the beginning of 2002-2003 season.

section.name: About Cayenne
section.p: Cayenne is a powerful, full-featured OpenSource Object/Relational framework. Cayenne is written in Java and is intended for Java developers working with relational databases. Cayenne has been successfully deployed in production environment on high volume sites. Cayenne has a growing international user and developer community.

Cayenne provides management of persistent Java objects mapped to relational databases, single method call queries and updates (including atomic updates of all modified objects), seamless integration of multiple databases into a single virtual data source. Cayenne is distributed with CayenneModeler - a complete GUI mapping tool that supports reverse-engineering of RDBMS schema, working with database mappings and generation of Java source code for the persistent objects.

Cayenne is an OpenSource project and as such encourages the community to participate in development, testing and writing documentation. This way we can produce a better product that will benefit both contributors and user community.
